content:
✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: I have confirmed that all grids have unique solutions. I have also tried to "retrofit" a pretty good handful of solutions from the original Sudoku Solver puzzle. Each solution could solve the first 2 test cases and validators for this 16x16 puzzle, but then timed out on everything that followed.

With this puzzle and the 25x25 puzzle, the author has done a really nice job of creating a "family" of Sudoku puzzles. The original Sudoku Solver is on the easy side of medium. This puzzle is on the hard side of medium. The 25x25 puzzle is definitely on the very hard side of hard.
How to approved ???

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: nice

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Donald Knuth is the smartest !

Hi
It's a challenging puzzle...
I wonder if there could be an increasing mechanic (2x2, 3x3, 4x4 and 5x5). I know that there are already puzzles with numbers in 2x2 (that of "nicola") and 3x3 (those of "AllTheKingsMen" and "redCroc"). Maybe in tests at the end, for fun?
THANKS

I can solve these all with my "smart" backtracking, non Algorithm X algorithm. If I leave out my logic that identifies a constraint that can only be covered by a single action, I can't solve any before timing out. I'd like to see test case 1 and test case 2 be solvable completely with logic, no backtracking at all - just like test case 1 currently is in your 25x25. If you do that, maybe add a 5th test case so there ends up being 2 test cases that work with only logic and 3 test cases that require logic + backtracking.
Done. We have now 6 tests, in increasing order of difficulty.

Hi,

Thank you for your comment! The choice that was made here is to provide a separate puzzle for each level, because these may require completely different algorithms, and that's what's interesting here.

You can find the 25x25 version here (and vote for it if you like) https://www.codingame.com/contribute/view/5565366ad6d449d56f7e91d450829b88dbb88

In fact it is possible to offer very difficult 16x16 grids, and rather easy 25x25 grids, but I preferred to put puzzles of different sizes for each level (also because having to manage several sizes with the same code adds unnecessary difficulty IMHO)

Hey darkhorse64! If you’re up for it, please take a look at this same author’s 25x25 submission that we both think requires DLX. This 16x16 is meant to be easy enough to solve with medium level backtracking logic. The author and I have been tossing around some ideas on how to make sure the two puzzles are truly distinguished as different - this one medium, the other hard/expert. Any thoughts you have would be much appreciated.
You must have at least level 20 of XP to approve
thank's I Understand

Already done but my DLX code fails to pass some tests: either it times out or it does not find a solution. I am rather puzzled because the same code has been used for several other DLX puzzles with success.

I had the same problem. I ended up solving it by changing the order of my columns. I also changed the order of my rows. I can’t remember if both changes were necessary. I’ll have to take a look. Essentially, I flipped my matrix A vertically and horizontally.

Changing the order of the columns changes how ties are broken when multiple columns are covered by same minimum number of actions. Changing the order of the rows changes the order in which the backtracking tries to cover some constraint. I really want to find a reason why the order I came up with works, but I have nothing so far.

My issues were always with timing out, never with not finding a solution.

Thanks,
It had escaped me: I'll take a look!

Validator 1 is the only one of the 12 I am solving with zero backtracking. How about you? I'd like T/V 1 and T/V 2 to all be solvable without backtracking. As far as 3 to 6, everything looks great. With my smart backtracking, nothing takes more than about 10% to 20% of max time limit.

Am I correct that different languages have different time limits? That is the reason I've been talking in pcts instead of times.

You're right, I checked with the wroong program. This is fixed now.

I don't know what is the time limit for each language, it's not under my control.

Are you sure you can solve test case 1 with no backtracking? I cannot. After my logic is applied, I have 78 unresolved cells. I'm good with V1 and T/V 2.

What is your approximate CG time limit in CPP?

I was wrong. Is it OK now ?

I guess the time limit in cpp is around 100/150 ms

Test Case 1 is good now. Can you make Test Case 2 and Validator 2 harder without needing any backtracking? I have two types of logic:

1) Is there only one candidate remaining for this cell?

2) Does this cell have a candidate that nobody else - could be row, col or box?

Right now T/V 1 and T/V 2 can all for be solved with #1 only. I'd like T/V 2 to both require both types of logic if possible to make them slightly more difficult than T/V 1.
I don't have the option to do that since my solver only uses strategy 1)

I will play with it on my end. 

Lastly, I’d like to make a few suggestions on the narrative. I think it would be powerful to emphasize that this is not just “yet another sudoku puzzle”. I have a couple of busy days. Give me a few days to think about some ideas for the narrative and I’ll shoot something to you. Maybe I’ll come up with something you like, maybe not. Either way, I think this will be a nice addition to the sudoku puzzle family on CG.

>> I don't have the option to do that since my solver only uses strategy 1)

Very interesting. With strategy 1 only, I timeout on T/V 3 to 6. I can <<usually>> pass everything with strategy 2 only, but my times all get a good bit slower.

Here's the really odd part. I thought strategy 1 was way more important than strategy 2. It looks like I'm wrong about that. I'll definitely need to investigate that.

>> I said >> Either way, I think this will be a nice addition to the sudoku puzzle family on CG.

FYI: I don't really think this puzzle is about Sudoku. This puzzle is about adding some intelligence to your backtracking, rather than brain-dead brute force backtracking. You and I have obviously both implemented DLX for the 25x25. For us, it's probably natural to think about adding smarts to our backtracking whenever possible. I think there is real power in this puzzle for the Codingamer that has maybe never given any thought to anything other than pure brute force. IMHO, that is the primary target audience.

I totally agree, for me too the interesting part here is to realize the importance of the choices that are made during a backtracking to reduce the search tree. In fact, this point is also applicable to many kinds of tree search algorithms.

I'm not very good at writing, and I'll be happy to see your contribution.
I sent a PM in the Forum.
